title: Dehydration: Assessing Kids Accurately (DHAKA) Score
description: Classifies dehydration severity in children under 5 years old with acute diarrhea using four clinical assessment parameters.

parameters.name: general_appearance
parameters.description: Child's general appearance and level of consciousness

parameters.name: skin_pinch
parameters.description: Skin elasticity test (pinch skin and observe return)

parameters.name: child_age_months
parameters.description: Child's age in months (must be <60 months for score validity)

parameters.name: diarrhea_duration
parameters.description: Duration of diarrhea in days (must be <14 days for acute diarrhea)

result.name: dhaka_assessment
result.description: DHAKA score with dehydration classification and management recommendations

ranges.interpretation: Child has minimal or no dehydration. Encourage continued fluid intake and normal diet. Monitor for signs of worsening. Continue breastfeeding if applicable.
ranges.management: Encourage fluid intake, continue normal diet

ranges.interpretation: Child has some dehydration requiring oral rehydration therapy. Supervised ORT with frequent monitoring for improvement or deterioration. May require closer observation.

ranges.description: Significant fluid loss requiring immediate intervention
ranges.interpretation: Child has severe dehydration requiring immediate intravenous rehydration and potential hospitalization. Close monitoring for complications and electrolyte imbalances is essential.

clinical_applications: Assessment of dehydration severity in children <5 years with acute diarrhea
Triage decision-making in emergency departments and primary care
Guiding rehydration therapy intensity and route of administration
Quality improvement in pediatric diarrheal disease management
Training tool for healthcare providers in dehydration assessment
Clinical research and epidemiological studies of childhood dehydration

no_dehydration: Encourage continued fluid intake and breastfeeding
Monitor for signs of worsening dehydration
Follow-up as needed based on clinical course
some_dehydration: Administer ORS solution according to WHO/UNICEF recommendations
Consider admission if ORT fails or tolerance is poor
severe_dehydration: Rapid assessment and stabilization of vital signs
Transition to ORT once clinically stable

references: Chisti MJ, Pietroni MAC, Smith JH, et al. Derivation and validation of a clinical dehydration scale for children with acute diarrhoea: a prospective cohort study. Lancet Glob Health. 2015;3(4):e204-e211. doi: 10.1016/S2214-109X(15)70015-1.

Pietroni MAC, Chisti MJ, Dewan ML, et al. External validation of the DHAKA score and comparison with the current IMCI algorithm for the assessment of dehydration in children with diarrhoea: a prospective cohort study. Lancet Glob Health. 2016;4(10):e744-e751. doi: 10.1016/S2214-109X(16)30150-4.
Goldman RD, Friedman JN, Parkin PC. Validation of the clinical dehydration scale for children with acute gastroenteritis. Pediatrics. 2008;122(3):545-549. doi: 10.1542/peds.2007-2134.
World Health Organization. The treatment of diarrhoea: a manual for physicians and other senior health workers. 4th rev. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2005.
formula: DHAKA Score = General Appearance (0-4 points) + Respirations (0-2 points) + Skin Pinch (0-4 points) + Tears (0-2 points)
notes: Score validated for children <5 years (under 60 months) with acute diarrhea
Acute diarrhea defined as ≥3 loose stools per day for <14 days
More accurate than WHO IMCI algorithm in validation studies
First dehydration assessment tool validated in low-income country settings
General appearance is assessed during examination and interaction
Deep respirations indicate compensatory hyperventilation for metabolic acidosis
Skin pinch test should be performed on lateral abdominal wall
Tear assessment requires observation during crying or distress
Score should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment
Not validated for non-diarrheal causes of dehydration
Consider underlying malnutrition which may affect assessment

validation.population: Children <60 months with acute diarrhea in low-income country setting
validation.evidence_basis: Derived and externally validated in Bangladesh with superior performance to IMCI algorithm
validation.clinical_utility: Validated tool for dehydration assessment in resource-limited settings with improved accuracy over existing methods
